name: rocket
content:
rocket

noun
 
 
/ˈrɒkɪt/
 
/ˈrɑːkɪt/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1.  
    [countable] a spacecraft in the shape of a tube that is driven by a stream of gases let out behind it when fuel is burned inside
    • a space rocket
    • The rocket was launched in 2007.
    • The idea took off like a rocket (= it immediately became popular).
    Wordfinder
    • astronaut
    • countdown
    • dock
    • launch
    • mission
    • orbit
    • rocket
    • satellite
    • space
    • weightless
    Topics Spaceb2, Transport by airb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • space
    verb + rocket
    • launch
    rocket + verb
    • blast off
    • lift off
    • take off
    • …
    rocket + noun
    • booster
    • engine
    • motor
    • …
    See full entry
  2.  
    [countable] a missile (= a weapon that travels through the air) that carries a bomb and is driven by a stream of burning gases
    • a rocket attack
    • A rocket smashed into the side of the building.
    Topics War and conflictc1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • long-range
    • anti-aircraft
    • anti-tank
    • …
    verb + rocket
    • fire
    • shoot
    rocket + verb
    • explode
    • hit something
    • strike something
    • …
    rocket + noun
    • attack
    • launcher
    • pod
    • …
    See full entry
  3. [countable] a firework that goes high into the air and then explodes with coloured lights
  4. enlarge image
    [uncountable]     (British English)
    (North American English arugula)
    a plant with long green leaves that have a strong taste and are eaten raw in salads
    5. Word Originnoun senses 1 to 3 early 17th cent.: from French roquette, from Italian rocchetto, diminutive of rocca ‘distaff (for spinning)’, with reference to its cylindrical shape. noun sense 4 late 15th cent.: from French roquette, from Italian ruchetta, diminutive of ruca, from Latin eruca ‘downy-stemmed plant’.
Idioms
to give somebody a rocket | to get a rocket
  1. (British English, informal, old-fashioned) to speak angrily to somebody because they have done something wrong; to be spoken to angrily for this reason
See rocket in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: rocket

name: rocket
content:
rocket

verb
 
/ˈrɒkɪt/
 
/ˈrɑːkɪt/
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they rocket
 
/ˈrɒkɪt/
 
/ˈrɑːkɪt/
he / she / it rockets
 
/ˈrɒkɪts/
 
/ˈrɑːkɪts/
past simple rocketed
 
/ˈrɒkɪtɪd/
 
/ˈrɑːkɪtɪd/
past participle rocketed
 
/ˈrɒkɪtɪd/
 
/ˈrɑːkɪtɪd/
-ing form rocketing
 
/ˈrɒkɪtɪŋ/
 
/ˈrɑːkɪtɪŋ/
jump to other results
  1. [intransitive] (+ adv./prep.) to increase very quickly and suddenly synonym shoot up
    • rocketing prices
    • Unemployment has rocketed up again.
    • The total has rocketed from 376 to 532.
    • Sales have rocketed by 213 percent.
    • They were forced to move out because of the rocketing crime rate.
    Topics Change, cause and effectc1
  2. [intransitive] + adv./prep. to move very fast
    • The car rocketed out of a side street.
  3. [intransitive, transitive] to achieve or to make somebody/something achieve a successful position very quickly
    • rocket (somebody/something) to something The band rocketed to stardom with their first single.
    Topics Successc2
  4. [transitive] rocket something to attack a place with rockets
    5. Word Originverb early 17th cent.: from French roquette, from Italian rocchetto, diminutive of rocca ‘distaff (for spinning)’, with reference to its cylindrical shape.
See rocket in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: rocket

name: Rocket
content:
Rocket

 
/ˈrɒkɪt/
 
/ˈrɑːkɪt/
jump to other results
  1. the name of an early steam engine (= vehicle that pulls a train) designed in the 1820s by Robert Stephenson. It was the first engine to be used regularly on the Liverpool and Manchester Railway, and the original version of it is now in the Science Museum, London.
Check pronunciation: Rocket

(North American English)

[uncountable]

name: rocket-fuelled
content:
rocket-fuelled

adjective
 
/ˈrɒkɪt fjuːəld/
 
/ˈrɑːkɪt fjuːəld/
(US English rocket-fueled)
[only before noun]
jump to other results
  1. happening, moving or increasing very fast
    • There are already signs of rocket-fuelled growth.
    • The firm has been achieving rocket-fuelled results.
    • The country has rocket-fuelled inflation.
Check pronunciation: rocket-fuelled

name: rocket science
content:
rocket science

noun
 
/ˈrɒkɪt saɪəns/
 
/ˈrɑːkɪt saɪəns/
[uncountable]Idioms
jump to other results
Idioms
it’s not rocket science
  1. (informal) used to emphasize that something is easy to do or understand synonym brain surgery
    • Go on, you can do it. It's not exactly rocket science, is it?
See rocket science in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: rocket science

name: rocket scientist
content:
rocket scientist

noun
 
/ˈrɒkɪt saɪəntɪst/
 
/ˈrɑːkɪt saɪəntɪst/
used especially in negative sentences (informal)
jump to other results
  1. an extremely intelligent person
    • You don't need to be a rocket scientist to figure out that this plan will not work.
    • He's a nice kid—maybe not a rocket scientist, but he's very sweet.
See rocket scientist in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: rocket scientist

name: booster
content:
booster

noun
 
/ˈbuːstə(r)/
 
/ˈbuːstər/
jump to other results
  1. (also booster rocket)
     a rocket that gives a spacecraft extra power when it leaves the earth, or that makes a missile go furtherTopics Spacec2
  2. a device that gives extra power to a piece of electrical equipment
  3. an extra small amount of a vaccine that is given to increase the effect of one given earlier, for example to protect you from a disease for longer
    • a tetanus booster
    Topics Healthcarec2
  4. a thing that helps, encourages or improves somebody/something
    • a morale/confidence booster
    Topics Change, cause and effectc2
  5. (especially North American English) a person who gives their support to somebody/something, especially in politics
    • a meeting of Republican boosters
See booster in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee booster in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: booster
